title: UST eyes repeat vs Ateneo
text:
by Christian Jacinto
October 21, 2015 Games Today
(Smart Araneta Coliseum)
2 p.m. – Adamson vs NU
4 p.m. – Ateneo vs UST
After avenging its lone defeat in the first round, University of Santo Tomas (UST) can now focus its attention to one bigger mission – a return appearance in the UAAP Final Four.
That will be their extra motivation when the Tigers collide with the Ateneo Eagles today in a match expected to relive their heated rivalry during the 2006 Finals.
Though they are coming off an inspiring 65-57 win over the reigning titlists National University (nu) Bulldogs, the Tigers are hard pressed to repeat their massive win over the Eagles in the first round.
DELA CRUZ
PERASOL
During their first round tussle, the Tigers had to rally from a 16-point deficit to beat the Eagles, 68-58.
If they can reaffirm their mastery over the Eagles, the Tigers will not only make another statement but will also regain the solo lead as the teams enter the crucial stage of the elims.
UST is currently tied with Far Eastern University (FEU) for the lead while Ateneo is likewise locked for third to fourth places with its bitter rival La Salle at 5-4.
One reason why UST Coach Bong dela Cruz is cautious this time is the return to form of Kiefer Ravena.
After misfiring in the team’s last four games, the high-leaping Ravena exploded for 20 points to help the Eagles clobber the Adamson Falcons, 87-72.
“A lot of people are questioning my shooting percentages, but with the help of my coaches, they really helped me pick my spots and put me in a good position for me to be comfortable. Siguro malaking bagay din na na-involve ko yung teammates ko,” Ravena.
Actually, Ravena fell two rebounds shy of completing a triple-double as he also finished with 11 assists and eight rebounds.
For University of Santo Tomas to repeat over Ateneo, Karim Abdul (left) and Kevin Ferrer (right) should have to play solid in both ends when the two schools clash today in the UAAP at the Smart Araneta Coliseum. The Tigers rallied from a 16-point deficit to stun the Eagles, 68-58, in the first round. (Ali Vicoy)
And that’s the major reason why Ateneo Coach Bo Perasol is upbeat going into their crucial showdown.
Perasol said Ravena’s superb all-around game has rubbed off on his teammates and that he is expecting another solid efforts his role players.
For Dela Cruz, it’s all about keeping the team tightly knit.
“Basta yung team at yung family namin kailangan every practice mag-improve kami. Every game kailangan nag iimprove din,” he said.
He’s also wary of the Blue Eagles as they had to storm back from a 16 point deficit in their first round meeting where they won, 68-58.
“Pag-aaralan namin ng maigi yung game sa Ateneo. Kasi last time lumamang sila ng malaki,” Dela Cruz said.
“Titignan namin kung ano mali sa game na yun at ia-adjust namin,” he added.
With a 3-6 record, NU needs to beat Adamson in their 2 p.m. showdown if it wants to turn its fortunes around.
Meantime, Ateneo’s seldom-used forward John Apacible has apologized to school officials, coaches and teammates for his drunken rage last Sunday that gone viral last Monday.
In the video, Apacible was seen yelling expletives at the man who’s filming the video and claiming that he’s a councilor.
